tweet: Thank you to @ALZIMPACT for letting me speak today about the important work you are doing to find a cure for this horrible disease.

We need a bias for action to find a cure for Alzheimer’s. 

I know the reality of this disease. My dad had Alzheimer’s and I experienced all the doctors visits and all the times he called me a name that wasn’t mine. 

We can only win if our community comes together to #ENDALZ. pic.twitter.com/zCr2t3JP0Q

Today marks the Persian New Year, Nowruz. This celebration spans various cultures and brings people together all across the world. I am excited to be able to observe this occasion with the people of my district and wish everyone a new year of joy and prosperity.
Tonight marks the end of Purim, a holiday where we celebrate the strength and enduring faith of the Jewish people. Happy Purim to all who are celebrating!

This #WomensHistoryMonth we recognize the remarkable strides women have made as business owners and entrepreneurs in the last few decades. Today, there are 12.3 million women-owned businesses compared to just 402,000 in 1972. #WomenHistoryMonth @HouseSmallBiz pic.twitter.com/VtPdBr0ZnB

Just released data shows the President’s unconstitutional emergency declaration threatens to steal tens of thousands of urgently needed DOD military construction funds from Maryland’s Fort Meade. This is unacceptable. I will vote to override the President’s veto next week.

Punishing first responders who carry naloxone is backwards and wrong. 

I'm proud to join Freshmen Working Group on Addiction Member @RepChrisPappas in introducing legislation that protects first responders on the front line of the opioid epidemic from unfair discrimination. https://twitter.com/RepChrisPappas/status/1108078967632875520 …

.@DetrickUSAG is doing such important work to protect our national security and to conduct life-altering medical research. Yesterday’s rocket attacks on Tel Aviv show the importance of congressional support for Israel. As a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, I will continue to fight for strong, bipartisan support for Israel, the Israeli people, and their ability to defend themselves.

My heart is with the victims of the Christchurch attack and the greater Muslim community.This act of hatred and intolerance is disgusting. We must stand against all acts of hate and Islamophobia around the world and unite around our Muslim brothers and sisters on this tragic day.
I’ll keep fighting to ensure the House offers paid internships in Washington and in House offices across the country.

However, I am disappointed that the House is only providing this funding for internships in Washington, DC. Members like me who wish to provide paid internships in District Offices should be able to do so as well.

Growing up on a farm that went bankrupt, it would have been tough for me to take an unpaid internship. I made a commitment to offer paid internships in my office, and I’m grateful the rest of Congress has funding to do so as well. @payourinterns  https://goo.gl/ZBmu5o

The Office on Violence Against Women is essential to helping survivors. Without the reauthorization of #VAWA it could be de-emphasized, merged, or consolidated. Let’s continue this service by reauthorizing #VAWA4ALL

The internet should be free and open. That's why I'm helping introduce a bill to restore #NetNeutrality so your internet service provider isn't able to control what you access online.

It's time to #SaveTheNet

We have so much work to do. I could not be more thankful to @repjohnlewis  and @FaithNPolitics for being our host this weekend and shining a light on the truths of our past and the work we must do to fight for a more just future.  #GoodTrouble #FPICivilRights 6/

Humanity has the ability to inflict such cruelty on each other. This powerful memorial shows the symbolic hanging of those we lost. 

In 2018 the Senate unanimously approved a bill to make lynching a federal crime. It’s only a shame that it took this long. 5/

One stop that sticks with me is the Visit to the National Memorial for Peace and Justice, which commemorates the millions that were targeted by racial terror lynchings. 

The brutality and terror that occurred in this country is sobering. 4/ pic.twitter.com/MojKaCaH4N

We have become the world's largest jailer - 25 percent of world's incarcerated people are incarcerated in the United States.

Now is the time for Congress to step up for REAL criminal justice reform. We have so far to go to address these glaring inequalities. 3/

Injustice is alive and thriving. We have an unjust criminal justice system that is a continuation of segregation from the sixties that is now manifesting itself in the mass incarceration of people of color. 2/
While heading back from a powerful and raw weekend on the @FaithnPolitics Pilgrimage led by Congressman John Lewis, I have some reflections that I wanted to share with you all.

Yesterday I met Amb. Caroline Kennedy and signed my name to the Wall of Tolerance at the Southern Poverty Law Center Civil Rights Memorial. On the 54th Anniversary of “Bloody Sunday,” we should all pledge to stand against hate and work towards a more just future. #FPICivilRights pic.twitter.com/xckqyrvWZn
This is reprehensible. Bigotry like this has no place in our country. https://twitter.com/pushkinforhouse/status/1101532563020148737 …
Great to be with my friend @RepRaskin on the @FaithNPolitics #FPICivilRights Pilgrimage this weekend! pic.twitter.com/bPzp06IDpj

Powerful words and beautiful voices filled Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church this afternoon, the starting point for the Selma to Montgomery Marches and the meeting place of the SCLC during the Selma movement. Another amazing stop on the @FaithNPolitics #FPICivilRights Pilgrimage. pic.twitter.com/5ZlFR86MFw

Marching across the Edmund Pettus Bridge linking arms with @repjohnlewis and so many others today made clear: we are all in this together and we must all continue the fight to protect what President Johnson so rightly called the ‘dignity of man and the destiny of democracy.’ pic.twitter.com/sqjxjSAZyW

“They came toward us. Beating us with knife sticks and bull whips. Tramping us with horses, and releasing the tear gas. 17 of us were hurt.”

It’s so humbling to be in the presence of American hero @repjohnlewis as he recounts what we now know as Bloody Sunday. #FPICivilRights pic.twitter.com/QbF9HHib6w

At the 16th Street Baptist Church with @repjohnlewis in Alabama and remembering the four young girls that were killed at a racially motivated bombing during the #CivilRightsMovement. We must never forget how far we have come, and how much work we still have to do. #GoodTrouble pic.twitter.com/WcZ0ZeubxI
